awd_titl_txt: MRI: Development of a system for low temperature optical measurement of 3D magnon, plasmon and spin torque transfer dynamics.
awd_abstract_narration:
Over the past 15 years scientists and engineers have realized that integrating logic and information storage functions could dramatically improve the energy efficiency of computing devices and enable new and more powerful computing paradigms. Promising materials for creating such a device include those materials in which electrical current strongly interacts with the spin of electrons. The spin of an electron can be thought of as a tiny bar magnet attached to the electron in which the north pole of the magnet can be oriented up, down, or in any other direction. To develop new computing platforms that integrate charge and spin functionality, it is necessary to study how these spins change direction in response to external stimuli such as electrical current or pulses of light. These changes occur very quickly in about one billionth of one second. This award supports the development of an instrument to study spin reorientation by measuring the spin direction with extremely short pulses of light that arrive at the sample at precisely controlled times relative to external stimuli such as an electrical current or a beam of light. Measurements will be carried out at very low temperatures to isolate and understand the fundamental physical processes. This knowledge will provide the scientific foundation for engineering appropriate materials for application in future computing devices. The work is being coordinated with a new graduate-level course on the materials under investigation and support the training of one postdoctoral researcher and two undergraduate researchers.


Spin-based phenomena in topological insulators and magnetic heterostructures have attracted a great deal of attention from the perspective of both fundamental science and device development. However, the underlying physical origin of many of these phenomena remains vague. Moreover, the dynamics of these phenomena, which are critical for device applications, remain poorly understood. This award supports the development of an instrument that will enable ultrafast optical measurements of collective magnetic and charge excitations and spin transfer dynamics at low temperatures and in three-dimensional magnetic fields. The new instrument will allow scientists to answer fundamental scientific questions about quantum materials, magnetic heterostructures, and other "quantum engineered" heterogeneous materials and identify routes to tailor these heterogeneous materials for spintronic, optoelectronic, and quantum device applications. The new instrument will enable the first ultrafast measurements of the dynamics of spin transfer torque. The three dimensional resolution and integrated optical, magnetic, and electrical control will allow scientists to separate, understand, and ultimately control competing processes. The instrument will also provide unprecedented measurement of magnon and plasmon dynamics in topological insulators and heterogeneous materials designed to control the emergence of interfacial phenomena with unique quantum mechanical properties. Successful development of the instrument will enable new interactions between fundamental science, applied science, and device engineering fields. It will enable the breakthroughs required for widespread adoption of "exotic" materials in device technologies. Conceptual aspects of the research enabled by this instrument will be integrated into new graduate and undergraduate courses and science education outreach programs. Members of underrepresented groups will be actively recruited for both the postdoctoral and undergraduate researcher positions supported by the award.

por.por_cntn:
Spintronics is the study of the behavior of both individual and collective electron spins inside a material, with potential applications ranging from lower-power-consumption electronics to quantum information processing. There are several collective orientations and excitations of spins that are of interest. For example, ferromagnetism arises when electron spins are all oriented in a single direction and antiferromagnetism arises when there is an ordered arrangement of spins pointing in different directions (e.g. up-down-up-down). A variety of physical processes such as electric current or optical excitation can cause changes in the magnetization, which is a measure of the collective spin orientation. Propagating spin excitations, in the form of magnons or spin-momentum locked plasmons, provide a potential tool for transferring or manipulating information. The primary goal of this project was to develop a new instrument that utilizes ultrafast optics to probe the magnetization and spin dynamics of samples held at low temperatures and in two-dimensional magnetic fields.

 The foundational technique of this instrument is the Magneto-Optical Kerr Effect (MOKE), which essentially measures very small rotations in the polarization of an incident optical probe beam induced by any magnetization in the sample. We developed the ability to implement MOKE probe measurements using extremely short pulses of light, which gave us the capacity to measure the dynamics of magnetization changes on ps time scales. We designed the instrument to accommodate both electrical current and optical pulses as the pumps that induced the magnetization changes. Moreover, the instrument was designed to conduct these measurements on samples cooled to temperatures as low as 4 K and to apply external magnetic fields along two different axes. Realizing this design required customization of component parts from a variety of vendors, renovation of a new laboratory space, and the development of measurement protocols that could achieve the required signal to noise level. A particular challenge was the design of the extremely high frequency connections (>40 GHz) required to retain the temporal precision in the electrical pump – optical probe experiments. We achieved the two-dimensional magnetic field control by installing and calibrating a permanent magnet that translates along the optical (z) axis of the experiment on the back side of the sample, which works in tandem with an electromagnet that provides fields along the x axis.

 The spatial resolution and integrated optical, magnetic, and electrical control provided by this instrument allow us to separate, understand, and ultimately control the competing processes that collectively result in changes to spin orientations. We now routinely run MOKE experiments utilizing both 405 nm and 780 nm lasers as a function of the two-dimensional magnetic field or at temperatures down to 4K. The capabilitis of this instrument are a key component of the research plan for three recent grants and have already enabled 4 scientific journal publications. We are currently applying the capabilities of this instrument to measure magnon and plasmon dynamics in topological insulators and heterogeneous materials designed to control the emergence of interfacial phenomena with unique quantum mechanical properties with possible applications in technologies including low-power computing and THz photonics.

With support from this award, two postdoctoral researchers and one graduate student were trained to conduct and report scientific research. The measurement principles of this instrument were incorporated into a graduate-level course on the optical properties of materials. Sustainable operation of this instrument for both internal UD users (from multiple departments / colleges) and external (academic and corporate) users is enabled by permanent staff support and the establishment of user fees that will cover ongoing maintenance and operations costs.
